newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Chinese buyers default on 150,000T soymeal - trade.
newsitem.headline: Chinese buyers default on 150,000T soymeal - trade.

text.p: Chinese buyers were said to have defaulted on 150,000 tonnes of soymeal bought from the United States due to falls in soymeal futures prices, traders said on Monday.
"There are three shipments, totaling about 150,000-tonnes, of U.S. soymeal (that have) been defaulted by some Chinese buyers," a U.S. trader in China said.

Dealers said Chinese buyers had bought over 500,000 tonnes of U.S. soymeal at a price of around US$300 a tonne C&F for nearby delivery, but some started to default on their purchases after soymeal prices fell recently to about $270 a tonne.
Traders said more Chinese buyers may default on their soymeal purchases and roll their contracts forward so they can take delivery at a later period for lower prices.
"Chinese buyers are still interested in buying U.S. soymeal at lower prices, despite the defaults," the Chinese-based trader said.
